questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician to evaluate a painful mass in her left breast for several days. She has no fevers or chills. She has not noticed any changes in the right breast. She has no history of serious illness. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 80/min, her respirations are 13/min, and her blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a palpable, mobile, tender mass in the left upper quadrant of the breast. Ultrasound shows a 1.75 cm, well-circumscribed anechoic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement. The patient says she is very concerned about breast cancer and wishes for further diagnostic testing. Which is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fine needle aspiration This patient's ultrasound findings are consistent with a simple breast cyst. Breast cysts are almost always benign, and further diagnostic steps are not routinely required. However, symptomatic patients, such as this patient, should undergo fine needle aspiration. Fine needle aspiration can be diagnostic and therapeutic for breast cysts (e.g., aspiration of a clear, non-bloody fluid resulting in a wholly collapsed lesion). Cytological examination of cyst fluid is no longer practised routinely as it is not cost-effective. The patient should be re-evaluated after 4–6 weeks for potential recurrence.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. A mammogram is indicated to evaluate breast mass in p atients > 30 years of age . In younger patients, however, breast tissue is hypersensitive to radiation exposure and very dense, thus limiting the utility of mammography. In addition, this patient's ultrasound findings suggest a simple cyst, rendering a mammogram dispensable. Option: C. Reassurance and follow-up is an appropriate approach for patients with an asymptomatic or only mildly symptomatic breast cyst on ultrasound. However, further diagnostic and therapeutic steps should be performed if the patient is concerned about symptoms. Option: D. Core needle biopsy is indicated in patients with a suspicious solid breast mass on ultrasound or mammography and those with malignant features on fine needle aspiration (e.g., a mass that does not wholly resolve upon aspiration). This patient's ultrasound findings, however, suggest a benign breast cyst.

questions.text: A 57-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician 2 weeks after noticing a lump in her right breast. Her last mammogram was performed 4 years ago and showed no abnormalities. Menopause began 2 years ago, during which the patient was prescribed hormone replacement therapy for severe hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right breast shows a firm, non-tender mass close to the nipple. There are no changes in the skin or nipple and no palpable axillary adenopathy. The abdomen is soft and non-tender; there is no organomegaly. Mammography shows a suspicious 2-cm mass adjacent to the nipple. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Core needle biopsy In a patient with a palpable breast lump and suspicious findings on mammography, an ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is the next best step to evaluate the extent of the tumour, confirm the diagnosis of breast cancer, and describe the histology of the tumour and its receptor profile. This test is essential for determining the most appropriate next step.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology cannot provide information about the tissue architecture or receptor status. Also, false negatives occur mainly through sampling error, and invasive cancer cannot be distinguished from in situ disease. FNAC has been superseded by a more sensitive and specific modality in patients with a palpable breast lump and suspicious findings on imaging. The primary role of FNA nowadays is the evaluation of nonsuspicious cystic lesions in women younger than 30. Option: B. Excisional biopsy (e.g., via lumpectomy) is an invasive procedure and is not the most appropriate next step in diagnosing breast cancer. It may, however, be used for diagnosis in this patient if the appropriate next step is inconclusive but imaging shows a suspicious lesion or if the appropriate next step cannot be performed (e.g., lack of facilities or expertise for ultrasound-guided procedures). Option: C. CA15-3, a tumour marker in patients with breast cancer, is used for the follow-up of patients who have already received treatment and not for the diagnosis of breast cancer.

questions.text: Six weeks after a spontaneous, uncomplicated term vaginal delivery, a 32-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, comes to the emergency department due to left breast pain. The patient first noticed pain and redness in her left breast a week ago. She has continued to breastfeed her infant from the unaffected breast. The patient has no chronic medical conditions, and her only medication is a daily multivitamin. Physical examination shows an area of erythema extending from the areola to the lateral edge of the left breast and surrounding a well-circumscribed, 4-cm area of fluctuance. Axillary lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Core needle and skin punch biopsies

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Needle aspiration and antibiotics The patient has a breast abscess based on signs of mastitis (fever, malaise, and localised erythema/pain) accompanied by a unilateral fluctuant, tender, palpable mass . Management includes drainage of the abscess with either needle aspiration (usually under ultrasound guidance) or incision and drainage .

Highyeild:

Breast abscesses typically develop from untreated mastitis (as seen in this patient), typically due to incomplete breast emptying (e.g., poor latch, alternating of breast and bottle feeds) and resultant milk stasis. In turn, persistent or severe mastitis can lead to a focal collection of purulent fluid (abscess). Mastitis and breast abscess are typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus , which enters the breast through nipple trauma (e.g., chafing/blistering). The diagnosis of breast abscess is made clinically, but ultrasound may be required to differentiate severe mastitis from an abscess if a mass is deep within the tissue. Management includes drainage of the abscess with either needle aspiration (usually under ultrasound guidance) or incision and drainage .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Breast binding is not recommended for breast engorgement, mastitis, or abscess because it increases pain and facilitates ductal blockage Option: B. Core needle and skin punch biopsies are indicated in evaluating inflammatory breast cancer, which can present similar to mastitis or abscess (e.g., unilateral breast pain, axillary lymphadenopathy). However, patients typically have peau d'orange skin thickening and a solid (rather than fluctuant) mass. Option: D. Warm compresses and massage are indicated in managing a clogged lactiferous duct, which can present with unilateral breast pain; however, the mass is typically located in the subareolar region and has no associated axillary lymphadenopathy.

Extraedge:

Empiric antibiotics against methicillin-sensitive S aureus (e.g., dicloxacillin, cephalexin ) are added to treat the surrounding mastitis. Continued breastfeeding is recommended for continued milk drainage.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Paget’s disease of the breast is usually associated with an underlying invasive carcinoma

options.label: B
options.text: The survival outcome following breast-conserving treatment and mastectomy are equal

options.label: C
options.text: Positive resected margins are a significant predictor of recurrence after breast-conserving surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy should not be offered in clinically node-negative axilla

questions.correct_answer: D. Sentinel lymph node biopsy should not be offered in clinically node-negative axilla
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sentinel lymph node biopsy should not be offered in clinically node-negative axilla Sentinel lymph node biopsy is offered in clinically node-negative axilla to rule out small nodal spread.

Highyeild:

Patients with Paget's disease of the breast may present with bloody discharge from the nipple, but the nipple and areola would appear erythematous, fissured, cracked, and/or ulcerated. Ultrasonographic findings are usually nonspecific with heterogenous, hypoechoic regions, skin thickening, and/or dilated ducts.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Paget’s disease of the nipple is an eczema-like condition of the nipple and areola and usually is associated with an underlying invasive carcinoma. Option: B. Evidence from several randomised controlled trials has shown that long-term survival outcomes are equal between breast-conservation surgery, radiotherapy, and mastectomy . Breast conservation therapy should be followed up with radiation. The local recurrence rates are high when radiotherapy is omitted following breast-conservation surgery. Option: C. Younger age, positive resection margins, high-grade tumours, extensive ductal carcinoma-in-situ (DCIS) presence and lymphovascular invasion are all important predictions of recurrence.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, comes to the clinic due to 2 days of right breast pain. She has also had a fever, chills, muscle aches, and fatigue. The patient had a spontaneous vaginal delivery 6 weeks ago and has been breastfeeding her infant. Her husband has been feeding their baby pumped breast milk so that she can rest at night. The patient has no chronic medical conditions and takes a daily multivitamin. Her mother was diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer at age 55. Temperature is 38.8 C (101.8 F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. Physical examination shows a 5 cm area of erythema, induration, and tenderness at the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and right axillary lymphadenopathy. There is no fluctuance. The left breast has no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue breastfeeding and prescribe antibiotic therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Perform incision and drainage and prescribe antibiotic therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe antibiotic therapy and continue breastfeeding

questions.correct_answer: D. Prescribe antibiotic therapy and continue breastfeeding
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prescribe antibiotic therapy and continue breastfeeding This patient has lactational mastitis , a common infection in breastfeeding women due to inadequate milk duct drainage from pumping breast milk (instead of directly breastfeeding} or poor latch. Additional risk factors include infrequent feedings (as seen in this patient sleeping through the night), nipple excoriations, and rapid weaning from breastfeeding. Patients with lactational mastitis are diagnosed clinically and typically have flu-like symptoms (e.g., fever, myalgias), focal unilateral breast pain with surrounding erythema and induration, and axillary lymphadenopathy. Lactational mastitis occurs when bacteria from the infant's nasopharynx or the maternal skin are transmitted through the nipple and multiply in stagnant milk. The most common pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus , and treatment is empiric therapy against methicillin-sensitive S. aureus with either dicloxacillin or cephalexin . Women with risk factors for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (e.g., recent antibiotic therapy, incarceration) are treated with clindamycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or vancomycin.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. In addition to antibiotics and analgesics (e.g., ibuprofen), patients should continue breastfeeding every 2-3 hours because direct feeding from the bilateral breasts drains the milk ducts. Option: B & C. Ultrasonography is indicated to assess for a breast abscess, which can present with fever, unilateral breast pain, and a fluctuant mass (not seen in this patient). Treatment of a breast abscess includes drainage and antibiotics.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman who is a chronic smoker complains of greenish nipple discharge on and off for 4 months. On examination, she has an irregular, firm lump deep in the areola, which looks indrawn. What will be the management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hadfield’s operation This patient has the typical features of duct ectasia – nipple discharge (not bloodstained), deformed nipple with retraction, and a subareolar indurated mass which may mimic carcinoma. The condition is caused by dilatation and inflammation of the ducts , leading to periductal mastitis . A carcinoma must be excluded by triple assessment. Treatment is by surgical removal of all terminal ducts ( Hadfield’s operation ).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: B. & C. are modified radical mastectomy that is performed for breast carcinoma, not for benign lesions like duct ectasia. Option: D . Radical mastectomy was performed for breast cancer but is not performed now.

questions.text: A 24 - year - old woman comes to the clinic with a breast lump she noticed 2 days ago. The patient's menstrual periods are regular, occurring every 26 days with 2 days of heavy bleeding and 2 days of light flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active and recently started using combined oral contraceptives. Family history includes a paternal aunt diagnosed with breast cancer at age 62. Physical examination shows a 2 cm, firm, round, mobile mass in the superior outer quadrant of the right breast. Which is the most appropriate method for confirming a patient's diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biopsy A palpable breast mass may be evaluated using the "triple diagnostic" (clinical breast examination, imaging studies, biopsy) approach based on the patient's age and risk factors for breast cancer. This patient's young age and palpable mass with benign features are most suggestive of fibroadenoma . Reassurance may be appropriate for an adolescent with benign findings that include a decrease in mass size after a menstrual period. However, further evaluation is needed to confirm a diagnosis of a new breast mass in an adult as the incidence of cancer increases with age. Although imaging tests (e.g., ultrasound and/or mammogram) are appropriate next steps in management, only a biopsy will confirm the diagnosis . A needle aspiration is performed for small cystic or solid lesions, while a core biopsy is preferred for larger solid masses.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. & B. In a patient aged < 30, ultrasound is the best imaging tool to distinguish between a cystic and solid mass. If ultrasound is concerning, mammography can be an adjunctive study to evaluate the entire breast tissue for features of malignancy. However, a mammogram is not a useful initial diagnostic modality in women aged <30 due to the increased breast tissue density. However, based on imaging results, only a biopsy will confirm what is suspected. Option: D. Excision of a breast mass (lumpectomy) is necessary if imaging studies and/or biopsy results suggest malignancy . Large, growing fibroadenomas may require lumpectomy for symptomatic relief, but a fine needle or core biopsy should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.
